The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gilbratar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Moday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at he very convienient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is $22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent on returnin within 12 months.
In addition to the above weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marsielles

div.head: CENSUS OF THE EMPIRE
div.p: The Blue Book issued last week dealing with the census of the British Empire taken in 1901 provides a feast for those who can derive enjoyment from a study of statistics, and even to the ordinary individual who hates to be compelled to wade through a collection of fact I and figures it is interesting to trace the remarkable development that has taken place in Greater Britain during the past 40 years. The results of the census are summarised in a long report by the Registrar General's Department and the President of the Local Government Board. From this it appears that at the time of the census of 1861 the Empire comprised in round numbers eight and a half millions of square miles. In the next two decennia no important territorial additions took place, but between 1881 and 1891 the extensions in the East Indies and in our Indian dependency and the great annexations of territory in West, South East, and Central Africa added about two millions of square miles. Since 1891 further expansions have occurred, principally in Africa and in Asia, raising the total as nearly as can be ascertained to 11,908,378 square miles Thus, in the short space of forty years the aggregate area of the British colonies, dependencies, and protectorates has increased by about 40 per cent, and now amounts to more than one-fifth of the land surface of the globe Of this huge territory somewhat more than four millions of square miles are situated in the North, Central, and South America, three millions in Australasia, two and a half millions in Africa, and nearly two millions in the Indian Empire and other parts of Asia, while the por­tion that lies in Europe constitutes a very inconsiderable fraction of the whole, amounting to only 125,095 square miles, of which 121,089 constitute the area of the United Kingdom.

As far as can be ascertained the population of the British Empire in 1861, inclusive of the Indian feudatory States, was about 259 millions. In 1871 it had risen to nearly 283 millions, in 1881 to nearly 310 millions, in 1891 (largely through acquisition of territory) to more than 381 millions, and at or about the date of the census of 1901 (exclusive of the population of North-western Rhodesia, for which no estimate could be obtained) it had reached a total of about 400 millions. For the whole Empire the aggregate rate of increase of population showed a great decline in the last decennium, and the report states that a large factor connected with the fall in the increase of the population is the continued depression of the birth-rate, which has now become general in nearly all countries. Excluding London, the most populous city in the British Empire at the present time is Calcutta, the population of which has grown from 10,000 or 12,000 in 1710 to nearly 843,000 in 1901. Bombay comes third with 776,000, and Glasgow fourth 761,000.

In the matter of religions, statistics are pre­sented regarding 319 millions, or about four- fifths of the total population of the Empire, no returns of religious belief being available for the remaining 79 millions of the population. Of the 319 millions more than 20 millions, ex­clusive of the population of Great Britain, were returned as professing one or another form of the Christian religion, and over 295 millions were returned under non-Christian religions, while the remainder, amounting to fewer than four millions, were returned and classed as either having no religion or as in­definitely expressed. If to these numbers are added the population of Great Britain (37 millions), and a further half million as repre­senting the Christians in the colonies where no religious census was taken, a total of 57 1/2 millions is arrived at as a rough estimate of the number of persons in the Empire professing one form or other of the Christian religion.

div.head: THE STEAM ENGIME IN ANCIENT EGYPT
div.p: Mr. G. Gerald Stoney, lecturing last week at Carpenters' Hall, London,on "Steam Turbines," said it was among the relics of ancient Egyp­tian civilisation, 20 centuries ago, that the first records of the steam engine were found. In Alexandria, the home of Euclid, Hero wrote his "Spiritalia sen Pneumatica," wherein he described two machines of special interest. The one utilised the expansive force of air in a closed vessel, heated externally, the pneumatic force being applied upon the surface of water in other vessels, and the hydraulic force utilised for opening the doors of Grecian temples, and working other pseudo-magic contrivances. The other was a veritable steam turbine engine, such, in principle, as they were discussing that night. It seemed doubtful whether this machine was ever more than a toy, or whether it was used by- the Greek priests for producing motion of apparatus in their temples. But from the experience of the last 20 years, it appeared that with some improvement in design and construction it could have been applied to perform useful work, and might have claimed a place among steam engines even up to the middle of the last century.

Only twenty years had elapsed since the Hon. C. A. Parsons brought out his compound steam turbine, and already there were at work and on order about 2,000,000 h.p. Practically the whole of the great power distribution schemes in the north-east of England were worked with steam turbines, but probably the most important field of usefulness for turbine engines lay in the propulsion of ships. Com­parisons between vessels propelled respectively by reciprocating and turbine engines showed an economy of coal of from 15 to 20 percent. in favour of the latter, and already there were on the Atlantic three great liners fitted with turbine engines. What might be the motive power of the future it was difficult to say. At present only 12 per cent, of the energy of the coal used in the very best steam engines was converted into work. One way to get over that difficulty would be to form a battery, using coal instead of zinc, and so to convert its ener­gy directly into electricity. Who could Bay that was impossible 1 What would our great-­grandfathers have thought of the "Flying Scotchman," the wonders of the telephone, and the gramophone, and the motor car ?

A native child of 2 years was yesterday playing alone in front ct its parents' house at Ramleh, near a heap ot watered lime, when it fell into the liu^and received serious burns, to which it shortly afterwards succumbed.

The Greek Consular Court has sentenced Mr. Constantine Komaoos, editor of "Le Sphinx,'' to two months' imprisonment, one hundred francs fine, and costs, for libel against Dr. Parissi of Cairo. 'Le Sphinx" has no con­nection whatsoever with the weekly Cairo season paper of the same name.

Yesterday ths Earl of Meath, Chairman of ] the Lads' Drill Assooiation, inspected the boys of Viotoria College, who were drawn op in three companies, one from the preparatory and two from the lower and middle schools. The boys went through their exercises and after march­ing past formed a hollow square round Lord Meath, who gave them an excellent address on manliness. This is the third oooasion on which Lord Meath has inspected the school.
Motor Oarage Fire.

About 6 o'olock last evening a fire broke out in a motor garage near the Telegraph Depart­ment's offices in the Boulao avenue, Cairo. There was a considerable amount ot benzine on the premises and the blaze soon assumed serious proportions, the flames lighting the neighbourhood for a considerable distance. Water could not be obtained for about twenty miuute8trom the beginning of the outbreak and the flames were thus allowed to get a good hold of the plaoe. The steam fife engine of the Cairo Fire Brigade did good work. The damage was considerable.Two omnibuses were destroyed.

div.head:
CHINESE LABOUR
GOVERNMENT POLICY
SPEECH BY MR. WINSTON CHURCHILL

div.p: Mr. WiDstoo Churchill yesterday evening demonstrated how the Government intended to put an end to the exportation of Chinese to the Transvaal when the outstanding licences had been oomoleted by, firstly, instructing the oonsuls in China to cease their co-operation, seoondly, by vetoing any proposals submitted by the Transvaal responsible Government which the Imperial Government considered derogatory to the fundamental principles of liberty and deoenoy.

He urged the miDe-owners to cease wringing their hands and to turn their energy to the disoovar/ of some less unnatural substitute for Cbrnewe labour. Mr. Balfour and Mr. Cham­berlain oonourre^ in warning the Government that they were entering on a dangerous policy in interfering with the vital affairs of a self- governing colony.( )
The sittings of the oonferenoe have now been suspended and a rupture is imminent: it is expected that the Government will now negotiate direot. (Rent*-)
Differences of opinion among the delegates at the Conference continue to exist,

div.head:
THE ARMY PROBLEM.
THE PROPOSED REDUCTION.

div.p: Mr. Seely moved the reduction of the Army Estimates by 10,000 men. Sir Ch. Dilke, in seconding the motion, condemned the linked battalions system and double! the possibility of reducing the number of battalions in Sooth Africa and in India.

Mr. Haldane deprecated committing himself before he had elaborated his ideas, but said that he felt that eoonomies were possible at home. He could put in the field with the reserves and the Militia 330.000 men. Reckon­ing on a striking foroe of three army corps, there remained the enormous sorplus of 2 0,000 men. Could not this be out down by reorganisation ? Nevertheless he asked the House not to fetter him.
He oonoluded by stating that he and the Army Counoil were doing their utmost to work out the problem of the army on the basis of the reduction desired.< Reuter)

div.head: OUR SPECIAL CABLES
div.p: THE VICB-PRE8IDBNCY.

As we stated yesterday,considerable sarprise has been evinced at the resalt of the eleotion to the po9t of Vioe-President of the Alexandria Municipality. Although everybody recognises that Dr. Schiess Pacha was an excellent ohoice, regret is manifested on all sides that Mr. Ambroise Ralli quits the post, which he has held for so many years with suoh exemplary devotion to the interests of Alexandria. During his long tenure of office Mr. Ralli has made himself popular with all olasses, and his depar­ture is deeply regretted by the personnel of the Municipality. The employes of the Muni­cipality, who presented Mr. Ralli onWedne°day morning with suoh handsome souvenirs of their esteem were quite unaware that there was any movement on foot among a certain aeotion cf the Coonoillors to ran a serious candidate against him. It is to be hoped that Dr. Sohiess Paoha will follow in Mr. Ralli's steps as Vioe- President and we have no doubt ha will fill the high position with the same dignity and esteem as his predecessor.

div.head: DEFRAUDING THE MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: Two members of a firm carrying on business in Alexandria were charged on the 14th inst. before H.B.M's Consular Court with conspiring together, and with a third person, to defraud, by means of a false lease, the Mnnioipality of Alexandria of a part of the amount of the 2% tenants' tax payable by them in respeotof their business premises. The oharge against one member of the firm was dismissed, but the other was oonvioted and fined £10, with costs.

div.head: GAZELLE SHOOTING.
div.p: At the present time it is impossible to get gazelle shooting in the neighbourhood of Alexandria, and one has to go a two days' journey from the oity to get within sight of the gazelle. There ought to be a splendid supply of these beautiful animals in the Mariout distriot for they breed very quickly and Mariout is a most suitable looality for their habitat.Unfortunately the Bedouins have been waging a war of extermination against them, for there is a great demand for th9m for oooking purposes, and within a few years' time they will become extinot unless some serions steps are taken to stop the sale. The Governor of Alexandria has accordingly issued an arrdtd to the effeot that the hunting and capture of female gazelles, as well as the sale and purohase of gazelles, alive or dead, are for­bidden within the distriot of the gonvernorat. It is also forbidden, but only in the first half of the year (1st January to 80th June) to transport, hawk, sell or bay the flesh of gazelles, without distinction of age or sex.

div.head: MONSTER CAIRO HOTEL
div.p: THE LATEST VENUE
TO HAVE GARDEN ON ROOF

Mr. Bucber-Durrer, the well-known Swiss hotel proprietor, who owns no less than ten big hotels in Italy and Switzerland, hao taken the leading part in the formation of a comoany oallsd the Soci4t6 Snisse Egyptienne des Hotels en Egypte, which will erect an immense hotel on the vacant ground this gentleman purchas­ed in the February of last year from Moi'se Cattaui Bey. The plot is situated next to the palace of the Khedivah Mother on the river embankment, opposite the Kasr-el-Nil barraoka, and measures 6,000 square metres. The designs of the building, which will be six stories high, have been prepared by Mr. T. Parvis, engineer and architect of Sharia El Madabegb, who will superintend the erectioD, and the contractors are Padova, L4on Rollin & Co., who have oontraoted to deliver the buildings ready for ibhtJguration on the 1st January next

The hotel whioh, i9 to be an ap-to-date one in every sense of the word, will contain at the opening 300 bedrooms, besides the usual offices, saloons, &o., bat it is intended to extend it for the following season by the addi­tion of 200 more bedrooms, thus providing accommodation for over 600 visitors in all. There wi'l be several small suites of apartments complete with private saloon, bathroom and lavatory, which will form one side of the building.

Qaitea new feature of the hotel, which should prove a great attraction, will be a roof garden after the style of those now to be foand prin­cipally in the big hotels of Amerios. Besides the garden there will be also on the roof a band-stand and two saloons oonnected by a glass covered corridor. From this elevated spot, where afternoon tea will be served, there will be a magnificent and uninterrupted view ot the surrounding country as far as the Pyramids.

As a proof of the increasing valae of eligible buildings in the best parts of the Capital we may mention that the plot of 6,000 Bqoare metres which M Bucher Darrer purcha-ed^laet year at £5 par metre he resold this year to the new oompany at £10. The next plot ofl,£00 square metres was bought a month after, in Marob, '905, by Mr. G. Higgibasiliou, pro­prietor of the New E-iglish Pharmacy, from Mr. P. Soares at £7.10 the metre and the latter has refased a recent offer of £15 by the same company.

An aotion brought by Mr. Haggibasiliou against Mr. Buoher-Darrer olaiming a right of pre-emption over the former plot, in the M'xei Tribunal of Cairo, wa9 decided against him last month with costs. An appeal has been lodged against this finding and it comes on for hearing before the Appeal Court of Alex­andria on the *8'h instant.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL AND RESIDENCES.
div.p: We mentioned some weeks back that the board of this oompany had deoided upon con­siderably extending their hotel for the coming season by the erection of an annexe which wonld add another 50 bedrooms to the hotel and bring up the total, including those in the resideDoes adjoining, to some 600 rooms. The foundations for the new building are now being got ready and the work of erecting the extension will oommence in the fi-st week of May, when the National will be olosed until nex* October.

The additional acoommodation will be ready for the 1st December and the expense is estimated at over £60.000. Th;s sum will in- olude the cost of several alterations and im­provements, of which one is a large and hand­some during saloon to replaoe the present salle h manger, which is then to be utilized as a restaurant. The amount required for this work is to be provided by a tnrther oall on the shares.

It is reported that the direotors intend recommending the payment in May of a divi­dend of 5 per oent. for the first six month0, being at the rate of ten per cent, per annum on the called-up capital of the company. Every praise is dae to these gentlemen as well as to Mr. Bauer, the courteous and indefatigable manager, for the excellent results already at­tained by the National Hotel, which was opened only a few months ago.

div.head: PROF. PETRIE'S EXCAVATIONS.
div.p: OPPORTUNITY FOR VISITING.

Professor Flinders Petrie writes from Tell el Yehudiyeh :—As many of yonr readers may like to avail them reives of the opportunity of examining our excavations, may I add the following details to faoilitate their visit.

Trains leave Cairo at 8.5 and at 11.80 a.m. for Shibin el Kan&ter, and return from there at 1.41 and 7.32 p.m. The jonrney takes an boar by rail, and Tell el YeHnd'yeh is 2 J miles from the station. Donkeys with stirrups are waiting in Shibin, or visitors who prefer to walk have only to keep sooth along the light-railway line till they reach our oamp.
The rained foundations of a Jewish temple are to be seen here, and the remains of Hyk8oa earthworks. We shall be very happy to conduot visitors over the site daring the next six days.

div.head: mena house
div.p: FACNY DRESS BALL
GAY AND FESTIVE GATHERING

Mena Honse was the sc3ne of a very gay and festive gathering on Wednesday night, when the annual fancy dress ball was in progress. It differed from the other fanoy dress balls of the season in so much that prizes were offered for the most original costume* worn by both ladies and gentlemen which had not exceeded 100 piastres in the fas-hloning.Cousequently,though there were some very handsome toilettes to be notieed, the greater number of them were distinctly fresh and delightfully original. The ardaoas task of judging their virioas merits fell to the lot of Mrs Boddam, Sargeon-General Sibthorpe, and Mr. G. Jackson, and every one was satisfied when the two prizes were awarded to Miss Loveless and Col. Ludlow, wbo°e cos­tumes fulfilled the various conditions. That of the former represented a pink lampshade and was ve>y cleverly fashioned of rose-coloured crinkled paper with a three flounced skirt and a very full frill round the shoulders and long trails of roses and satin ribbon as trimming. CoL Ludlow appeared as Mena House, in a flowing raiment of the gaily-oolonred hangings known as Mena House curtains and with a oleverly fashioned cardboard Pyramid on his head. Upon his back he bore the inscription, "See the minx by spoonlight, and dine at Mena Honse."

Very much to be commended was Miss Ewarts' becoming get up as Cleopatra, the long olassieal robe being made of hotter mnslin with a Greek key pattern border of gold tinsel. Mr. Ewart was one of the successes of the evening as a Lady of the Present Day. Hi-* make-op was most splendid, and in his well­fitting black dress, fashionable ooiffure, and large hat. it was diffioult to real'zs that he was wearing unaooustomed garb. He acted the character well, too,and made an exceeding­ly handsome and elegant belle. There was a certain amoont of alarm when a dreadfully realistic) tramp appeared open the scene, and it took some minntes to discover the features of Mr. Bishop beneath the fsrooious make up of the patched and r gged mendioant who loudly demanded baksheesh. Mrs. Valentine Smith made a very handsome Duchess ot Devonshire in her blaok velvet gown and laoe fichu, and with the traditional wide-spreading hat upon her powdered ourls, and Mme de Vries wa9 also very striking in her L<unhalle ooiffare with its wreath of roses. Miss Morritt made a very attractive L'Entente Cordiale, and MisB Bentley was a charmingly sweet Bo- peep, while her younger sister enjoyed herself as a Flower Girl. Mrs. Lndlow was wearing a very delicately oolonred Kimona with flowers and fins in her hair d la japonaise, and there was a very oleverly designed dress wherein the trimmings sapplied the title headings of many a well-known newspaper. Mrs. Bishop was one of the nursing sisterhood. Amonrst the gentlemen in fimey dre-a we noticed Mr. BeDnett as Pipoator, Mr. Temple as a 8ayoe, Mr. Bacon as the Knave of Hearts. M-. Biff- dnlph as M>phi»topheles,and Dr. Waekilng as a Bedouin sheikh.

Many people there were who contented themselves with ordinary evening dress, among tham being: -Count and Countess Welsbur?, Prinoess Mwrooorda^o, Prinoe De- melar Ghika, Sir Thomas and Lady Aoland, Ge- oral and Mrs. Lanoe, the Hon. Bellamy Storer, Mr. J. Nichols, Mr. and Mrs. G. Macintosh, Rev. and Mrs. Warrand. Mr. Farrar and the Misses Farrar, Mr. Daveen, Hon. Mrs. Carsons, Mr. Maloolm Lloyd and family. Admiral Henry Kane, Mr. Chas. Wool- Stan, Gereral Sir John Ardagb, Count Ga- larzi, Mrs. Bishop, Mr. and Mrs. Soctt Dilgleish, the Misses Harley, the Misses York, the Misses Blytb, Miss Ambridge, Miss Whittaker, Mr. Armstrong, Mr. Green and Mr. Allen. Needless to say the arrangements for the ball were as perfect as they could be. The Bracale band provided entertainment for those who were energetically incl:ned, and for those who passed the time away in the soft and calmy air outside in the verandah or in the gaily illuminated garden. The danoing floor was well nigh perfect and Dover too orowded for comfort, and the open win­dows prevented it from being overheated. A well-stocked bnffet supplied the material wafcts of the inner man, and the motley throng of pleasure-seekers provided all that was neoessary for social well-being.

div.head: THE AKABA QUESTION
div.p: The Akaba question is beginning to attract considerable attention in Europe. In the latest issue to hand of the Parisian "Eolair" there is an important article entitled "La Route das lodes" wherein on a map of the shore of the Red Sea, it shows the parallel between the Alexaudria-Caifo-Khartonm line and Beyroat* Damasans-Meoci roate. We extract the fillow- ing passage:—

" L'Angleterra a vu aveo irritation se faire !q chemin de fer da Hedjsz, de Damas h la Mecqae, destine à assurer l'aotoritl da Soltan en Arabie et à faoiliter la mobilisation de ses troaj es. Le chemin de fer du Hedjsz, le ohemin de fer de Bagdad 4chappant Dos deux à l'in- floeuce aDglaiae et touohant de si pr&saux grandee routes des Iodei, sont consid5r5s par la politique britanniqne comme deux dangers, contre leaqaels elle latte aveo toute son 3ner- gie.

" Or, il eat question de relier Ei-Akaba à Mian sar le ohemin de fer da Hedjsz; on a mdme lanc6 l'id4e de oonstraire eatre le golfe d'El Akaba et la M^diterran^e an second cmal donblant celni de Saez.

" La mer Rouge, ch l'Angleterre ohaqae jonr assarait ses positions par ses empi&tamente h Aden et à Cheik Sail, par la oonstraotion da chemin de fer de Berber Port-Soadan, ne lui appartieod'ait pins en propre: l'ennemi serait install^ dans la plaoe.

" Elle voit le ddveloppement d'El Akaba aveo antant d'irritation qae l'italie sarveille Trieste ou Pola; et o°tte jaloasie est mieax jostifita, oar la possession de la route des Indes est one quastion vitale poor l'Angle- terre, tandis qae l' "Adriatiqae italienne" n'eat qa'nn rflve lointain. "
SUDAN'0U8TOMS RETURNS.
The first monthly retnras from the recently formed Sadsn Customs hive just been publish­ed. They relate to January 1906, and show the clearances through Saakin and Port Sudan.

With regard to Suakin, the imports daring the month amounted to L.R 6,484, cf which India was responsible for L B. 2,893 and Great Britain LE. 1,750. The prinoipal trade done was in cloth, the return being one of L.E.

list.item: 485, India sending LE. 1,718 and Great Britain L.E. 733. Tbe provision figures totalled L.E. 524, sagar L.E. 498, wines L.E. 456, and ootton goods L.B. 880.

div.p: To the above-mentioned imports of L. E. 6,484, there must be added L.B. 9,750, being the value of goods from abroad sent viA, Egypt, and admitted into the Sad&n duty free on acooont of the oharges having already been oolleoted at the port of entry.
The exports from Suakin amounted to L.E.

list.item: 529, Egypt being the highest buyer with LE. 1,989, and Great Britain the lowest with LE. 276. The ohief item in the exports was senna leaves, LE. 1,190, all of which passed into Egypt. Goode to the extent of LB. 8,833 were carried by coasting 'vessels from Suakin to Port Sadan. the main trade being in pro­visions, LK 1.919.

div.p: In the case of Port Sudan, the imports reaohed L.E. 1,689, largely due to o- ment ship­ments, which figure for LK 1,217 in the re- tarns. Tbe exports were valned at LK 76.

div.head: FLEECING THE TOURIST.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—I am a common or garden tourist visiting Bgypt to 3ee :ts monuunputs, to breath its Bplendid air, to e> its sunshine, and to escape the fogs and inctamenf le* ' f a London winter. For this I have eacr ? endured the exactions of porters, dragomans and doukey boys, because the eummer someth when no man can work. I have oheerfally paid twice the price I should have paid on the continent for hotel aooommodation because I know that shareholders are olamorous. Bot my latest experience of the Egyptian tradesmen is suoh as to make even the patient British tourist ass tarn. A sadden illness oompelled me to have a prescription of a very simple cha­racter made up at 10 p.m. a few nights ago. The chemist in this town who supplied it demanded and obtained 40 piastres for this bottle of medicine which I have had sapplied since for 8 piastres, because, as he said, "anyone com'Dg at 10 p.m. for medioine mast be prepared to pay for that indisoretion." Messrs. Cook and Sin, in their pamphlet, ad vise all tourists coming here to provide themselves with "money and plenty of it," and I have tried in a modest way to profit by their advioe, bi t really no balance at the bank would be sufficient if one is to have many dealings with tradesmen such as are to be found here.
I am, eto., Poorer and Wiser.
Helouan, March 14.

div.head: CORPORATIONS OF WESTERN EGYPT
div.p: The following is the text of a circular which baa been issued to the ghareholders in the above oompaDy :—

One of the memberg of the Board, Mr. Edward Manville, M. Inst. C.E., hag recently returned from Egypt after having made a careful inspection of the railway now in course of construction and investigating the affairs of the Corporation with a view to securing the economio development of the valuable and exclusive land, railway and other tights pertaining to it in the Western Oases of Eeypt, under the concessions granted by the Egyptian Government. As a result of his scrutiny, Mr. Manville is now enabled to assure the Board that the Corporation's affairs are under competent and able manage­ment in Egypt, and to satisfy them that the polioy of deferring land sales on a large scale pending the completion of the first seo tion of the railway (a polioy adopted after deliberative decision and announced in the annual report issued last Deoember) was a wise and prudent one.
Railway.

Prior to the arrival of the rolling stock ^consisting of three looomotives built by Messrs. Nasmyth, Wilson & Co., of Man­chester, and of sixteen wagons, bail* by the Metropolitan Amalgamated Railway Carriage and Wagon Company, of Birmingham), when much better progress may be looked for, the work of oonstrnotion is being effeoted with the assistance of rolling stock hired or pur­chased from the Delta Light Railway, and has already resulted in the completion of the platelaying to kilometre IS, while the formation is completed to kilometre 42 and the ballasting laid to kilometre 46. Telephone wires are now laid from the junction with the Egyptian State Railway as far as the base at El Earnao, where buildings for the accommodation of the headquarters staff, stores and offices are being erected. Pomps in connection with the railway watering ar­rangements have been set up and are working most satisfactorily.

The sorvey party has prepared the detail plans and seotions and staked ont the centre and level pegs up to kilometre 91}, and the consulting engineers report th-*t "there has been no difficult) in so laying ont the line as to provide fairly easy gradients and onrves without an undue lengthening of the route and without anything in the nature of what can be considered heavy works." It remains to locate and level the route from kilometre 91) to the top of the Khargeh eoarp (at abo-1 145 kilometres aooording to the original measurements), a work which it is anticipated will be effeoted within some two months from the present time.

From the top of the Western soarp a survey of the route into the Oasis of Khargeh has been simultaneously carried on, and the line is looated, levelled and staked out to Ain Meheriq. It will be remembered that a steep gradient, some 1 in 25, was regarded here as unavoidable, hut so soooesefol bas been the survey made recently under the personal supervision of Mr. J. Edward Waller, M. Inst. C.E, of Messrs. Kinoaid, Waller, Manville and Dawson, consulting engineers to the Corpora­tion, that a no worse gradient than 1 in 40 may now be looked for, a gradient which as compared with that first mentioned will in­crease the carrying oapaolty of a train com­posed entirely of goods wagons by no less than 100 per oent.

Little difficulty is anticipated on the final seotion. that from Ain Meheriq to Khargeh. where a terminal station will be situated which has been looated with due regard to facilities for extending the line either in a westerly direction to Dakhla, or in a southerly direction to Beris.
Land.

The work of locatirg cultivable arena and of preparing plans in connection with the formal applications to the Covert ment is steadily proceeding, while on the areas po looated, the policy of the board is direoted to the demon­stration of the artesian supply by means of bore holes, and the aotual cultivation of plots of the adjoining land so as to evidenoe the possibilities of the soil. Although in view of the board's policy in regard to land alluded to above the Corporation has not yet advertised land for sale, the applications already register­ed considerably exoeed the areas surveyed to the present.

It should also be remarked that the anticipa­ted saleable value of the land would appear to have been under estimated, since a valuation made by a large landowner of Assinut tends to show that the land will rpa ise a pinimnm prioe of no less than £15 per feddan. The cost of irrigation is estimated at about £5 per feddan. „
Satisfactory progress is being made w th well- boring, full artesian supplies of water bjing obtained at depths varying from 230 fpet to 350 feet.

The cultivations are of promising appaaranoe, the agricultural chemist reporting that the wheat is very uniform in growth and gives promiss of a very good orop indeed. Sugar cane, rice, barley, beans and other crops are also doing wel1, while young orarge, lemon, aprioot, olive, fig, pomegranate and peach trees are being planted in the vireyard near bore No. 2. Upwards of 1,000 date palms have also been planted, and large unmber of vine cuttings proooied from a good grower Land preparation for cotton is proceeding ; 33 fed- dans at bore No. 9 are sat up in drills and are ready to be planted.
MlnaraH.

Under instructions from Mr. Bertram Blonnt, F. I. C., consulting chemist to the Crown Agents for the Colonies, who is advisirg the board in the matter of mineral development, the ohief ohemist in the Oases is engaged in superintending the extraction of the sulphate of alomina from the ex'eusive aluminous deposits by a simple process of leaching. The aluminiom sulphate with its valuable cobalt oontent will be stored pending the completion of the railway, when it will be exported to London and placed on the market. Tie cin- snlting chemist's reports tend to show that a very handsome profit will be reused.

An experienced chemist is further engaged in analysing the samp'es sent in by the pros­pectors, who are actively exploring the Oases. Extensive old workings have Veen located, full reports upon which are shortly expeoted.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT AND BRITISH FRIMS
div.p: We have lately received a number of com­munications on the subjeot raised in an artiole entitled "Trade and Diplomacy," which ap­peared on February 14. To some of these we have already given publicity ; bat it would appear that inquiries have been made into some of the allegations of our correspondent respecting the reputed apathy of British Government officials abroad towards British trade interests, with the result that, in one osbo at least, circumstances are adduced which tend to remove to a material degree the damaging tendenoy of a portion of our cor­respondent's arraignment. With rjgard to the erection of the Saganeb Reef Lighthouse, the contract for which, it was stated by our cor- respondent, was placed, throngh diplomatic influence, with a Continental firm, to the detri­ment of Briti-h firms who had incurred a large amennt of trouble and expense in pre­paring estimates for its oonstrnotion at com­petitive prices, another correspondent writes:— "1 had an interview yesterday with Mr. Mit- ohell Innes, Under secretary for State, who had the placing of the order in question. Mr. Mitchell Innes absolutely and most empha­tically denies the truth of the statement. He sent for the dossier containing all the papers relating to the tenders, and he read ont to me extraots from the Government engineer's re­port on the various tenders. This was to the effeet that the three lowest should be passed over, on the ground that their

specifications were meagre " and their "designs faulty," leading the engineer to the conclusion that none or these firms had gone properly into the matter or really under­stood what it was that they were tendering for. The next lowest tender was that of Messrs. Schneider, of Creusut, and as this firm's speci­fication waB dear and detailed a»d the design satisfactory, the order went to them as being the lowest tender offering a suitable proposal. Mr. Mitchell I> nes assured me that from the first to last the French Government had nothing whatever to do with the matter, and that they did not approach the Egyptian authorities on the subject, directly or iudireot- ly." Our correspondent proceeds to Bay "I may remark tha*I think it is undoubtedly the case that foreign Governments do a great deal more for their own mapufacturera than onr Government does, or is likely to do, but I do not believe that in Egypt the authorities would be in the smallest degree influenced by any representations made to them on behalf of a foreign firm by their representatives here. If we can only put in tenders, specifications, and de-igns, and so on, as full and oareful as thosa submitted by the foreigners, I think we shall be sure to have preference, and, of course, it is a great pity that the British in the past have been so slack in this particular part of the world."

Another correspondent, writing from Egypt on the same question, says : —"British firms here have recently been getting the lion's share of everything, and have no legitimate cause of complaint. My own experience leads me to the conclusion that they would do well to re member that a little tact and politeness are good oomteeroial assets. I have heard freqnent complaints of the bad manners of their agents, which are contrasted by British officials with the politeness of the various foreigners. Also they do themselves harm by making groundless complaints like that which was commnnioated to the writer of your artiole. The officials in Egypt would be more than human if they did not somewhat resent misrepresentations of th's kind." It may be noted that exception haabeen taken, so far, to only one of a number of oases niwd by onr correspondents as to the lack of diplomatic assistance of the kind stated to be freely accorded by foreign competing Powers to commercial representatives of their natio­nality abroad

Another correspoudent deals more minutely with the Saganeb oflntraot. He Btates that eigh tenders were Bent in for this undertaking, of which five were from British firms, two from French and one from a Belgian firm. The lowest offer for the work was £21,' 00; the highest, £79,?5'\ Qur correspondent oitea 'he n»mes of the firms tendering, with the amounts of their tenders; and concludes that the offer of Messrs. Schneider and Co , of Creosot, was acoepted by the Ministry for "the oombired merits of excellence of design worked out detail and the moderate price of £32 900 "

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries ET BOUTIGNY.
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 10 mars.

A Londres, le Consolidé anglais a hanssé hier de 1/8 à 90 7/8 et TUnifiée de 1/1 à 105 1/2. La National Bank et l'Agricole sont restées invariées à 27 5/8 et 10 1/*. LaDsïra Sanieh a baissé de 1/8 à 17 3/4.
A Paris, l'aotion Crédit Foncier Egyptien
est renseignée en reprise de 2 francs à 7 94 et
la Banque d'Athènes de 1 franc à 145.
Notre marohé des valenrs a été, ce matin encore, très aotif et très ferme sur plusieurs valeurs.

La National Bank, toujonrs inert9, est restée à ses prix d'hier. Plus animée, l'Agri oole s'est insorite à 10 1,16 l'action ancienne, et 9 5/8 la nouvelle. La Cassa di Soonto a haussé de 210 à 216. L'aotion Crédit Foncier a progressé à 791 et l'obligation à lots 1836 à 342.
L'aotion Immobilière a avancé à 392 ; la part de fondateur à f59. La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil est montée à 7 1/2.
La part de fondateur Enterprise and Deve­lopment est revenue à 17 1/2. La part de fondateur Land Allotment a atteint 177 pour olôturer à 168.

L'aotion Société d'Entreprise3 Immobilières et Travaux s'est maintenue à 4 1/2 ; on ne tardera pas certainement à voir des oours plus élevés. La part de fondateur a atteint jusqu'à L. E. 19 1/2 pour olôturer à 18. On sait qu'il avait été déoidé, dès la constitution de la Société, de subdiviser ohaque part de fonda­teur en 25 couperas. Les nouveaux titres seront mis en oiroulation dans deux mois.

L'aotion Brasserie des Pyramides est montée à 133 ; la part de dividende à 79. Un mouve ment de hausse sérieux semble se dessiner sur oe titre ; on affirme que la Société est en train de conolnre la vente de ses terrains à des prix extrêmement avantageux.
Les Omnibus du Caire sont à 27 aohetenra.

Dans le groupe des Hôtels, il y a eu des transactions très importantes sur les National, qui ont atteint 4 5/8. Le public commence à s'intéresser à oe titre, dont la hausse parait devoir s'aooentuer rapidement. Les acheteurs sont sérieux

Parmi les petites valeurs, fort mo ivement de hausse—que nous avions prévu depuis longtemps—sur les Cotton Mills ; on a clô­turé à 8 sb. 6. Les Oasis ont également avancé à 1 5/8. Les Sait and Soda restent à 24 sh. 6. Les Estâtes ont fait 2 3/16 ; la part de fondateur a enoore gagné £ 1 1/2 à 12 5/8. Les Egyptian Constructions sont revenues à 1 11/16.

Il y a lieu de s'attendre Bur les Agricoles du Nil à un mouvement de hausse, qui serait d'ailleurs justifié par les brillantes opérations faites par la Société. Une seule d'entre elles a, paralt-il, donné un bénéfice de 11,000 livres.
Il ne faut pas, d'antre part, perdre de vue le revenu rapporté par le beau domaine acquis Tan passé. Bien que oonsigné au milieu de l'année, l'exploitation agrioole de oes terrains
donne déjà un profit "net" de 4 à 5 pour cent.
On assure que l'émission publique de la Gairo Heliopolis Metropolitan Eleotrio Rail- way Co. (Oasis du désert de l'Abbassieh), aurait lieu dans le coarant du mois pTochaiD.
La oapital social, s'élevant à 15,<"03,000 de franos, est représenté par 60,000 aotions de 210 francs chacune, entièrement souscrites par les fondateurs.
La proportion qui serait offerte au public serait de 20 %, soit 12,000 aotions.
La souscription serait ouverte simultané­ment an Caire, à Bruxelles et à Paris.

Diverses rumeurs sont en oiroulation au sujet de la hausse qui vient de se produire sur les aotions de la Western Egypt Corporation (Oasis). Le bruit a couru hier en Bourse, au Caire et à Alexandrie, qu'une mine de houille avait été découverte sur les lieux.

Ce qui est certain, o'est que la Sooiété a organisé une expédition chargée d'explorer l'oasis Maluk, qui passe pour être très intéres­sante au point de vue minéralogique. Cette expédition se mettra en route dans un dizaine de jours.

Les Oasis sont introuvablea. Par suite d'achats insignifiants le oours est remonte ce matin à 1 1/2 aoheteurs, sans vendears.
De forts eohanges ont eu lieu en Cassa di Soonto qui olOture l'anoienne k 217 et la nouvelle à 215.
La Delta Light est tiks ferme à 12 5/8.

Eu revanche la National reactionne l«5g6re- ment à 28 1/16, la Behera k 38 3/4, la Daira à 18 1/16 lea Estates à 2 1/32 l'aotion et 12 1/2 la part, de fondatear, les Nnngovich à 18 1/2, les Upper Egypt Hotels de 5 13/16 à 6 9/16.
Dans l'ensamble, la tendanoe est excellente.

div.p: La rdaotion qui s'est dessinde oes jonrs derniers sur les titres de la Sooidtd d'Eatre- prises Immobilizes et de Travaux est due uniqnement an fait qne le Conseil d'Adminis­tration a ddoidd de faire effeotner le denxidme versement de L.E. 1. par aotion. C'est lk une de ces petites depressions qui se prodnisent invariablement sur les aotions de tontes les Sooidtds chaqne fois qn'il est fait appel de fonds. A moderate business has been done thin week, and prioes have advanoed in sympathy with Fatnres, Brown being raised j^d. @ f par lb., and Upper ^ per lb.
In Fatnres a large business has been done, and fiaotnations have been, sometimes, very great. The following are latest quotations :—

To­day's dosing prices are 1 @ 4 points higher for Old Crop, but unchanged @ 4 down for New Crop positions, from those of last Thurs­day. There is no speoial feature, oontinned large takings by spinners have failed to stimu­late prioes, in hoe of absence of speculation. It is a waiting market in f&ot.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN THE US
div.p: The attempts to grow Egyptian ootton in the United States have not been attended with much snooe88. Daring recent years several planters have grown it, bat only very small yields have been obtained. At the Blaokehear Experimental Plantation in South Georgia, the four varieties, "Abassi," "Ashmouni," ' Yan- novitch" and "Mitafifi," have been grown □nder various forms of manorial treatment. At another plantation a hybrid between Sea Island and Egyptian cotton has been cultivat­ed. As already stated, all the Egyptian oottons and the hybrid were badly affected with "black arm." The disease on the Egyptian ootton was so severe that the prospective yield of eaoh variety was rendered insignifioant. So little saooess has attended these attempts to grow Egyptian ootton in the States that Mr. Orton, the noted pathologist to the Bureau of Plant Indastry, U. S. Department of Agrioultnre, is said to have expressed the opinion that there if no hope of its being extensively onltivated. ("Cotton Cultivation in the United States," in the "Imperial Institate Bulletin/')

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
